rev.diff:
Line 235: Line 235:
{{seealso|List of 64-bit Linux distributions}}
{{seealso|List of 64-bit Linux distributions}}
â
[[Linux]] was the first operating system kernel to run the x86-64 architecture in [[long mode]], starting with the 2.4 version prior to the physical hardware's availability.{{Fact|date=October 2007}} Linux also provides backward compatibility for running 32-bit executables. This permits programs to be recompiled into long mode while retaining the use of 32-bit programs. Several Linux distributions currently ship with x86-64-native kernels and [[userland (computing)|userlands]]. Some, such as [[SUSE Linux|SUSE]], [[Mandriva Linux|Mandriva]] and [[Debian|Debian GNU/Linux]] package both 32-bit and 64-bit systems on a single DVD-ROM image to allow automatic selection of the best software during installation. Other distributions, such as [[Ubuntu (Linux distribution)|Ubuntu]], are available in a version compiled for 32-bit and one compiled for x86-64 architecture.
+
[[Linux]] was the first operating system kernel to run the x86-64 architecture in [[long mode]], starting with the 2.4 version prior to the physical hardware's availability.{{Fact|date=October 2007}} Linux also provides backward compatibility for running 32-bit executables. This permits programs to be recompiled into long mode while retaining the use of 32-bit programs. Several Linux distributions currently ship with x86-64-native kernels and [[userland (computing)|userlands]]. Some, such as [[SUSE Linux|SUSE]], [[Mandriva Linux|Mandriva]] and [[Debian|Debian GNU/Linux]] package both 32-bit and 64-bit systems on a single DVD-ROM image to allow automatic selection of the best software during installation. Other distributions, such as [[Ubuntu (operating system)|ubuntu]], are available in a version compiled for 32-bit and one compiled for x86-64 architecture.
===Mac OS X===
===Mac OS X===
Line 287: Line 287:
* [[BSD]] systems such as [[FreeBSD]], [[NetBSD]] and [[OpenBSD]] support both AMD64 and Intel 64 under the architecture name "amd64".
* [[BSD]] systems such as [[FreeBSD]], [[NetBSD]] and [[OpenBSD]] support both AMD64 and Intel 64 under the architecture name "amd64".
â
* [[Debian|Debian GNU/Linux]], [[Ubuntu (Linux distribution)|Ubuntu]], and [[Gentoo Linux|Gentoo]] support both AMD64 and Intel 64 under the architecture name "amd64".
+
* [[Debian|Debian GNU/Linux]], [[Ubuntu (operating system)|ubuntu]], and [[Gentoo Linux|Gentoo]] support both AMD64 and Intel 64 under the architecture name "amd64".
* [[Java Development Kit]] (JDK): The name "amd64" is used in directory names containing x86-64 files.
* [[Java Development Kit]] (JDK): The name "amd64" is used in directory names containing x86-64 files.
